Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Gladysz. Professor Gladysz is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at Texas A&M University and is developing novel gyroscope-like metal complexes. Macroscopic gyroscopes serve as devices for sensing and/or maintaining the orientation of an object (e.g., space stations; torpedo warheads; virtual reality headsets; mobile phone displays; drones; flying insects via biological assemblies termed "halteres"). The classic mechanical gyroscope, encountered by many as a childhood toy, consists of an axle, a flywheel that can rotate, and a protective housing. When the object is displaced from its axis of rotation, there is a restoring force arising from the conservation of angular momentum. The underlying physics holds at the molecular level, allowing chemists to pursue the limit of gyroscope miniaturization. This project is directed at the synthesis of molecular gyroscopes that contain a metal based flywheel contained in a novel cage-like structure anchored by two phosphorus atoms that are 180Â° apart. The ease of rotation of the flywheel is maximized, and the demonstration of gyroscopic properties sought. These systems are linked to give "gearboxes", and investigated as catalysts for fine and commodity chemical syntheses, for which metals are commonly required. Since the metals are confined to a restricted space, it is hoped that new selectivities based upon reactant or product size or shape can be realized.

This project focuses on the synthesis, fundamental structural and dynamic properties, reactivity, and applications (molecular devices, catalysis) of gyroscope-like metal based molecular rotors. These most commonly feature a trans-diphosphine ligand in which the phosphorus atoms are spanned by three chains, usually of the formula (CH2)n (n > 10) but also incorporating hetero-atoms, p-phenylene groups, or other functionalities. They are accessed by three-fold intramolecu-lar ring closing metatheses of precursors of the type trans-LyM(P((CH2)mCH=CH2)3)2, followed by C=C hydrogenation (n = 2m+2). The coordination geometry may be square planar, trigonal bipyramidal, or octahedral (y = 2-4). If the ligands (Ly) are sufficiently small relative the (CH2)n linkages, the LyM unit may rotate within the gyroscope cage. Arrays of gyroscope like units with parallel axes are synthesized with spacings that allow the rotators to interact, enforcing correlated motion such as in gearboxes or waterwheels. The metal fragments are extruded from the gyroscope cages, providing a heretofore unknown class of macrocyclic dibridgehead diphosphines. These are independently synthesized, combined with various metal species to form new gyroscope-like complexes, and (in view of their ability to turn themselves "inside out") investigated as "transport containers" for toxic or harmful metal species.

Performance_Institution.Name: Texas A&M University Dept of Chemistry

POR.DRECONTENT:
The findings associated with this project have a significant impact upon fundamental chemistry and point the way to diverse types of possible future practical applications. Everyone is familiar with the technologically important all-carbon polymers graphite and diamond, which are derived from sp2 and sp3 hybridized networks, respectively. However, fewer are aware that a third polymeric allotrope is possible, "carbyne", derived from a sp hybridized network (in the form of a one dimensional chain). This material has remained difficult to access. Hence, this study, which has made the synthesis and characterization of models for carbyne possible, has helped to define exploitable properties. 

Another thrust has involved the miniaturization of machines and devices to the smallest possible level (namely molecular). Thus, new methodologies have been developed for the construction of (1) (insulated) molecular wires based upon carbyne segments and (2) molecular gyroscopes that structurally resemble traditional mechanical toy gyroscopes. In appropriate cases, the gyroscope cages can be detached from the rotating components, giving rare examples of molecules that can "turn themselves inside out". In one form, key atoms (usually phosphorus) direct their binding sites inwards, and in the other form key atoms direct their binding sites outwards, towards the environment. This "inside-out" property allows the phosphorus containing species to serve as "container molecules" and transport precious metals away from base metals (for example, platinum and palladium away from nickel). This is conceptually similar to harvesting gold from sea water, which remains an objective for future work.

This "inside out" phenomena has been further exploited to engineer molecules with totally new types of connectivities or topologies, related to the types of knots and similar structures that are well known from the basic training exercises of Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts.

The research involving carbyne has a direct impact upon polymer science, providing new materials with new properties, quite analogous to that of graphene. The molecular wires and molecular gyroscopes have a direct impact upon nanotechnology. In particular, gyroscopes are ubiquitous in modern technology, and all of the physics holds at the molecular level. To name just a few examples, all mobile phones now have gyroscopes that maintain the proper orientation of the graphics on the screens, and have further use in gaming applications. Furthermore, all drones use gyroscopes for orientation and navigation. For obvious reasons, there is ongoing pressure for increasing miniaturization, for which the ultimate would be a molecular level device.

The research activities have provided training and educational development for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral associates, high school teachers, and visiting Professors, not only as researchers but as teachers and leaders. These have included a significant numbers of women and underrepresented groups who have garnered many awards and fellowships. The broad technical, intellectual, and presentation skills acquired via this project provide a very strong foundation for future careers in a number of fields. In depth safety training has also been an intrinsic part of this project. 

The PI and all coworkers participate in a variety outreach activities, such as the annual chemistry department open house, where they carry out a variety of demonstrations involving gyroscopes.   They have organized local meetings where the emphasis is on the diversity of the outside speakers.

All aspects of the data generated by this project (collection, storage, protection, retention, analysis, sharing, reporting) are administered according to a rigorous "data management plan". All doctoral dissertations completed within the framework of this project have been placed online by Texas A&M University and are available free of charge to the public.

Gyroscopes are essential components of a variety of consumer products, many of which are considered "empowering" from the standpoint of enabling new ways of acquiring knowledge, facilitating new types of social interactions, and allowing access of lay personnel to what have traditionally been closed or difficultly entered fields. Thus, there is the potential for transformative impact upon the way individuals lead their lives. Also, gyroscopes would undoubtedly play a key roles in (for example) technologies required for a return trip to the moon or the colonization of Mars.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/01/2019
Modified by: John A Gladysz
